_prev_prog_3.Description: The prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of acetaldehyde and a CBI flammable substance.  These chemicals are used to produce specialty organic chemicals.  FutureFuel uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling and storage of the chemicals.  The protective systems include PHA's, deluge systems, continual training, frequent inspections, and preventative maintenance.

Prevention process describes the safe storage fo formaldehyde.  This chemcial is used to make a variety of specialty chemicals.  FutureFuel has multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling of this chemical.  The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventative maintenance programs and automated control systems.

Prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of phosphorus oxychloride.  This chemical is used and generated in the process.  FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure safe handling of phosphorus chloride.  The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventative maintenance programs, and automated control systems.

Prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of bromine.  Future Fuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure dafe handling of bromine. The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventative maintenance programs, automated control systems, and monitoring systems.

Prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of trimethylamine.  FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure safe handling of trimethylamine.  The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventative maintenance, and automated control systems.

The prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of vinyl acetate (drummed).  FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling and storage of this chemical. The protective systems include PHAs, combustible gas analyzers, continual training, frequent inspections, and preventive maintenance.

The prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of phosphorus oxychloride.  FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure safe handling of this chemical.  Protective systems include PHAs, continual training, and frequent inspections.

Prevention process describes the safe handling of anhydrous hydrogen chloride. The chemical is used to produce organic chemicals. FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling of this chemical.  The protective systems include, PHAs, preventative maintenance, automated control systems, frequent inspections, and continual training.

Prevention process describes the safe storage of oleum in the NOBS area.  This chemical is used to make a variety of organic chemicals. FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure safe handling of oleum. The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventive maintenance programs, and automated control systems.

Prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of phosphorus trichloride.  This chemical is used as a raw material.  FutureFuel Chemical Company uses multiple layers of protection to ensure safe handling of phosphorus trichloride.  The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventative maintenance programs, and automated control systems.

Prevention process descibes  the discharge of chlorine from the railcar to the process.  Chlorine is used to produce a variety of organic chemicals.  FutureFuel uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling of chlorine.  Systems include Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), continual training, frequent inspections and assessments, preventive maintenance processes and monitoring systems.

Prevention process describes the safe storage of 30% Oleum.  This chemical is used to make a variety of organic and specialty chemicals in the OCI area.  FutureFuel uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling of Oleum.  The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, frequent inspections, preventative maintenance programs and automated control systems.

Prevention process describes the safe handling of anhydrous hydrogen chloride.  This chemical is used to produce photographic intermediates and other organic chemicals.  FutureFuel uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling of this chemical.  The protective systems include PHAs, preventative maintenance, automated control systems, frequent inspections and continual training.

The prevention process describes the safe handling and storage of propylene.  This chemical is used to produce photographic intermediates.  FutureFuel uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling of this chemical.  The protective systems include PHAs, continual training, preventative maintenance, deluge systems, frequent inspections, monitoring systems and automated control systems.

This prevention process describes the storage and handling of ethyl mercaptan.  Ethyl mercaptan is used to produce a variety of organic and agricultural chemicals.  FutureFuel uses multiple layers of protection to ensure the safe handling and storage of this chemical.  These systems include PHAs, continual training, monitoring systems, preventative maintenance, automated control systems, and frequent inspections.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Inde. Co. Loc. Emer. Plan. Com.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FutureFuel Chemical Company.: RMP Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

FutureFuel Chemical Company, (FutureFuel) is located on a 2200 acre site near Batesville, Arkansas. FutureFuel is a manufacturer of specialty organic chemical intermediates.  Some of the chemicals manufactured at FutureFuel include: paint and coating additives, intermediates used in plastics, household detergent ingredients, agricultural products, and bio-based products.  FutureFuel has RMP regulated flammables consisting of ethyl mercaptan, acetaldehyde, a CBI flammable substance , trimethylamine and propylene.  In addition, the facility uses chlorine, oleum (30%), anhydrous hydrogen chloride, formaldehyde, phosphorus oxychloride, phosphorus trichloride, vinyl acetate and bromine which are RMP regulated toxic substances. 



The FutureFuel plant site has a long-standing history of protecting the health and safety of employees, the community, and the environment.  This is evidenced through over 20 years of safe operations and excellent environmental stewardship, through our commitment to the principles of Responsible Care®. To protect people, property, and the environment, we use multiple systems-or layers of protection-where one system is designed to backup another system.  The first layer involves accident prevention by identifying and reducing risks during the design and before startup of new manufacturing processes.  The second layer involves operating and mantaining equipment and processes in a manner that reduces risks and minimizes incidents.  The third layer involves maintaining the capability to respond to and control incidents in a timely manner.

 

All RMP covered processes at FutureFuel are regulated as Program 3.



Five Year Accident History

FutureFuel is committed to a goal of providing a workplace that is free of accidents.  Our record over the past years indicates good progress toward that goal.  There has been one injury involving a RMP

chemical.

Date/time 8-30-18 10:21 am

Chemical - Chlorine

Quantity released - 0.9 lb

NAICS code that closely corresponds to the process - 32519

Type of release and its source - Chlorine vapor from a valve

Weather Conditions 73F, wind S 2 mph

On-site impact - 1 OSHA recordable injury from inhalation of Chlorine

Know off site impact - none

Initiating event and contributing factor - a small chlorine vapor leak from a valve gasket.  the operator in the area did not have personal protective equipment as required by procedure.

There have been zero incidents with off-site effects.  





General Accident Release Prevention Program Steps

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at FutureFuel.  Because processes at FutureFuel that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



Employee Participation

FutureFuel has management systems in place which meet the requirements of RMP and ensure full employee participation.   The Plant Safety Council was developed to provide oversight, direction, and coordination of site and department safety programs to ensure safety excellence.  



FutureFuel encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees have access to extensive information created as part of FutureFuel accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees are involved in the accident prevention program are documented in employee participation plans that address each accident prevention program element.  In addition, FutureFuel has a number of initiatives underway that address process and employee

safety issues.  These initiatives include FutureFuel's Leading Indicators Process which is a process for reporting safety concerns and ensuring that such concerns are addressed promptly.  



Process Safety Information

FutureFuel keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design information.  This information is normally compiled in a Process Safety Information (PSI) binder or filed electronically. The PSI and referenced documents are readily available to employees as part of the employee participation plan.



Process Hazard Analysis

FutureFuel has a comprehensive Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards before the manufacturing process begins.



FutureFuel uses a PHA technique that is appropriate to the complexity of the process being studied.  There are four techniques in use at FutureFuel.  These are Check List, What If, What If-Check List, and Hazard and Operability Analysis.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating, maintenance, chemical, and engineering expertise and experience.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures.



Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on the relative risk rankings assigned by the PHA Team.  These rankings help ensure  accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA Team findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each findin

g is documented and retained for the life of the process.



All processes undergo a revalidation PHA at least every five years as long as the process is active.



Operating Procedures

FutureFuel maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as: 1) unit startup, 2) normal operations, 3) temporary operations, 4) emergency shutdown, 5) normal shutdown, 6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and provide the basis for consistent training of new operators. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the Management of Change Process.  The Production Manager certify these procedures annually as accurate.  The Process Safety Review Committee reviews them at least every five years.  



Training

To compliment written procedures for process operations, FutureFuel has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  Each new employee receives basic training in department operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is provided training on process-specific duties and tasks.  This is done through an operator training program or by pairing the new operator with an experienced operator for an appropriate period of time.  After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skill demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they may work independently.  Refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  Training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



Contractors

FutureFuel uses contractors to supplement its construction, maintenance and related services workforce.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, FutureFuel has procedures in place to provide contractors information on the

hazards in their work area.  In addition, FutureFuel has a process for the selection of contractors and evaluation of their safety performance.  





Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

FutureFuel conducts a PSSR for any new process, new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of a PSSR is to ensure safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and supporting systems are operationally ready. 



Mechanical Integrity

FutureFuel has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: 1) conducting training, 2) developing written procedures, 3) performing inspections and tests, 4) correcting identified deficiencies, and 5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Safe Work Practices

FutureFuel has long-standing, documented safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include: 1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, 2) lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, 3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, 4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and 5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed sa

fely.



Management of Change (MOC)

FutureFuel has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), operating procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating, maintenance, and contractor personnel are provided  necessary training on the change.



Incident Investigation

FutureFuel promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could result in; fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to company management.  Corrective actions are implemented in response to the investigation team's findings and are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and the investigation results are reviewed with employees and contractors who could be affected by the findings.

 

Compliance Audits

To help ensure the process safety program is functioning properly, FutureFuel conducts compliance audits at least every three years to determine whether the required procedures and practices are being implemented.  A specialized team from the HSE Department conducts these compliance audits.  Audit findings are forwarded to company management for resolut

ion.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



In addition to the PSM required audits, FutureFuel conducts numerous internal safety inspections and HSES assessments.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all FutureFuel processes, not just RMP covered processes.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by either equipment or human failures.



FutureFuel also has safety features on processing units to help: 1) quickly detect a release, 2) contain and control a release, and 3) reduce the consequences of a release.  Some examples of safety features that compose the layers of protection at FutureFuel are gas detectors/analyzers, relief valves, scrubbers, automatic shutdown systems and containment areas.



Emergency Response Program Information

The overall emergency response program for FutureFuel is coordinated with the Independence County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  The LEPC includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The committee meets regularly to develop community emergency response plans and to conduct community-wide drills.  FutureFuel has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  FutureFuel also conducts its own periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and/or emergency response organizations.  FutureFuel provides annual information and refresher training (more frequently if necessary) to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances at FutureFuel

. 



FutureFuel has a written emergency response program in place to protect employees, contractors, the public, and the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated or non-regulated substance.  The procedures address the aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after the evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and the post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, FutureFuel has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training on these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to FutureFuel processes or other company facilities. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

FutureFuel resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  The following are current activites of the Plant Safety Council:



1.  Reinforcing a strong safety culture

2.  Continue support of Responsible Care

3.  Providing Root Cause Analysis training for additional employees.
